ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: It was good exposure to different guest speakers to get an understanding for the different fields in biomedical engineering as a whole.
I learned about different aspects of the field of biomedical engineering and how to get involved with research and career opportunities as a sophomore
Introductory material in to the Biomedical Engineering field. Really got great insight into the field and great perspective about summer jobs, the career opportunities, and research opportunities.
I learned mainly about careers and research in biomedical engineering.
learned about the different field in BME, very insightful
I learned about the variety of things I can do with a BME degree, including the many different options I have at Yale for course selection and paths.

I learned a lot about up and coming innovations in biotech and what work research laboratories at Yale are doing. I also learned about what steps to take to prepare for a career in industry or research.
Applications and futures in BME, as well as the opportunity to meet professors and upperclassmen in the field.
I learned about the biomedical engineering field, the tracks Yale offers for the major, and the types of careers the field produces.
Insight into different major tracks and career paths for biomedical engineering. Helpful panels from current students and professionals.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I like how the class focuses on bringing guest speakers, however, the variety of guest speakers could be improved, even though it was already quite good.
It is interesting for BME majors.

strengths: very interesting guest speakers, tailored to our interests and lots of opportunities to ask questions and learn more about biomedical engineering
weaknesses: some of the guest speakers' presentations were too technical, would've preferred they focused more on their career journey instead of the specific things they were doing
I thought the course was very well organized and that Professor Rodriguez did a great job in lining up great guest lectures that offered great advice!!

Strengths: light coursework fosters career exploration. There's lots of guest speakers-- students, professors, and professionals-- who talk about their work and it was always a treat listening to them. It's a nice break from your other BME classes, as there's not much work and all you really have to do is be present and engaged during the one class period per week. 

Weaknesses: not much advice on applying to med school as a BME major. Most of the advice centered around BME research and working in industry or consulting after graduation. I wish they brought in more guest speakers who applied to medical school (not MD-PhD) after their undergraduate studies in BME.
strengths: speakers that came in, the engaging assignments

Strengths: invites a wide range of professors, students and professionals into class to speak with students. Almost all of the presentations were incredibly engaging. 

Weakness: Besides the group orject, I did not feel I really got to know the other students in the class. Would be nice to do more assignments with others or do ice breaker questions or something at the start of class to get to know my peers -- especially bc this is the first time all of the BMEs are really together.

A huge strength of the course was the format of having guest lecturers each week that were often members of the Biomedical Engineering faculty at Yale or other relevant biotech employees. This made the course function like a series of TedTalks which was super engaging and interesting. I came each week excited to learn. No weaknesses!

More inclusion of industry and biotech speakers. I feel like this class was very premed-dominated, and polls throughout the semester reflected this, but I felt that didn't allow for as much diversity within the other applications of bme.

Strengths - Guests were brought in to speak about the various tracks of biomedical engineering. We had multiple panels with Yale College BME seniors and grad/med students doing something related to BME. The class only met once a week. The work was pretty minimal. 

Weaknesses - The discussion posts were due at 11:00PM because Professor Rodriguez wants to ensure we made thoughtful posts, but I think theyd be just as effective if the deadline was 11:59PM.
Very interesting topics that were applicable and answered many of my questions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, because it helped me find my research lab. However, in my opinion, there was way too much of a focus on consulting/venture capital, and not enough of a focus on grad and med school.

It is only required for biomedical engineering students, but if you need another half credit and dont necessarily want to do too much work, and are interested in the different aspects of biomedical engineering, it is not a bad choice at all.
Yes. It was really interesting.
definitely, especially if you are thinking about doing biomedical engineering. it is a great way to learn about how to get involved more in the field
yes!!! I would recommend this course for Biomedical Engineering students!
If you're a BME major, you are required to take this course. Even if it weren't, I'd still recommend anyone at least interested in BME to take it and see if they like the field.
yes, especially if you are considering BME because it a required class
Yes! A wonderful course for all BMEs.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, even someone who is not a Biomedical Engineering major. It was super interesting and an extremely light workload (which aligns with its status as a half credit class). If you are at all intrigued by the idea of a career in biotech, I would recommend this course.
Yes, this course was very helpful and informative for anyone interested in BME and/or Premed.
Absolutely. If youre a BME major, its required, but it still provides a nice overview of the BME field.
Yes for those wondering what tracks or future careers are available to biomedical engineers.
